The murder mystery element is the traditional style of whodunit. You're dropped right in to early 50's small-town England, and all the sets are flawless, which is what we've come to expect. Post-war Britain was a lot more austere than what we see here, but the characters do seem to be realistic, rather than corny caricatures. Our hero is a vicar/reluctant detective, played by the handsome and able James Norton, with enough vices to keep him interesting.  He forms an easy friendship with the police inspector, played by the ever dependable Robson Green, who seems at first to be quite hard-boiled but we soon see is a rather cheerful family man.

It appears to be a worthwhile addition to the crowded field that this genre has become, but just different enough to set itself apart, which makes it definitely worth watching.
Enjoyed this very much. Interesting, good characterizations. Peaceful (for a murder mystery). I look forward to many more. We could all use some stress-reduction instead of what we usually get on TV.

Having read one of the Sydney Chamber's novels a few years back, I must confess to being somewhat disappointed in the televised series, which, with each ensuing episode, is rapidly spiraling into a more uninspired - and uninspiring - mystery featuring an Anglican priest who is fairly adept at solving crime, as was the character from the novel, yet unlike his fictionalized counterpart, the series leaves much to be desired in the portrayal of this drinking, smoking, spiritually apathetic priest.

Changes have also been effectuated to the script that irreparably distorted the original mysteries, making them dull and contrived, while also adding elements of crassness here and there which are nonexistent in the book.

Based on its own merits, Granchester does have potential. While the storyline lacked originality, and plodded along too predictably, the characters of Chambers and Inspector Keating are the only noteworthy aspects to emerge from the hash that was made of it. This is one instance where the adaptation did not simply lose the flavor of the books - it simply lost all flavor whatsoever, however, James Norton and Robson Green do their absolute finest with the rather prosaic material. I am willing to continue watching in the hope for improvements, but those changes will need to be profound if Granchester is to be salvaged.

When gruff Detective Inspector Geordie Keating (Robson Green) first encounters Anglican vicar, and WWII vet, Sidney Chambers (James  Norton) he is annoyed.  The good vicar thinks D.I. Keating's recent closed case suicide might really be a murder.  After bonding over backgammon, D.I. Keating comes to realize the vicar's warm and sympathetic manner coaxes secrets from witnesses, and potential suspects, which makes the vicar a potential asset and ally.

Set in post-war 1950's Cambridgeshire - near Cambridge - in the village of Grantchester, the scenery stars along with the inspired choice of actors. Cambridge is used for some street scenes. James Norton as the lanky and fair vicar is a non-judgmental, boyish vicar with whom you would like to go to the pub - he prefers strong whisky over the more clerical sherry choice. Interestingly, in real life James Norton has a spiritual bent. Norton read theology at Cambridge and journeyed to Nepal where he became intrigued by Buddhism. The non-preachy, non-doctrinal spirituality adds a little depth to this series which is refreshing. Robson Green as the detective inspector combines twinkle with grumpiness, and for comic interludes, Mrs. McGuire (Tessa Peake-Jones) is the taciturn, disapproving housekeeper of the vicar who judges everyone and everything, including the dog.

There are a few potential love interests to add spice to the series, but the real action portends to be in the crime-solving relationship of Detective Keating and Vicar Chambers.  For anglophiles, this will probably be a 5-star series as it has the necessary ingredients: a detective and sidekick (although the vicar functions more as the leading amateur detective with his understanding of human nature and ability to solicit secrets), a gobsmacking attractive English backdrop with proximity to Cambridge, engaging supporting characters in the form of a housekeeper, some love interests, and a really cute black lab puppy combined with whodunits to solve.  Another season has already been commissioned, so you won't be left wanting for too long once this six-episode season is over.  The series is based upon mysteries written by James Runcie.

It may have been the Dreary Fifties (at least in the U.S.) but it's anything but dreary in a new series (for us here in the States) that has certainly caught my eye and my attention.

  It is "Grantchester"!  Set in 1953, which surely was a trying time  in the U.K. as the War had been over only eight years, this series seems to set that aside and instead dwell upon a scenario that the Brits do best:  police detective stories on both the telly and in excellent books.  Combining (for the better) Father Brown with touches of Graham Greene ( and relying upon others for the basic premise), this series is a pure delight.  Alas, each segment is only an hour each (at least in Series 1), but that aside, it certainly commands the viewer's attention.

Young Sidney Chambers (James Norton) is the vicar of Grantchester, a small town near Cambridge.  One would think that such a quaint village would be dull, even boring for a vicar, its citizens, and even the constabulary, but fiction kicks in and dull doesnt appear in the vocabulary. Sidney, a veteran of the War himself, finds himself faced with all sorts of predicaments, precarious situations, an uncertain personal life, and, yes, murders.  He soon finds the local detective inspector (Robson Green) to be sympathetic and willing to listen to his ideas about "who done it."  They make a good team, after an initial slow start.  Of course, there's the smothering motherly housekeeper and a new puppy and a romantic interest designed to keep us waiting for the next episode:  will they or won't they?

But murder's the game (or at least solving it) and this series handles it quite well. Kudos to the creators.  (I see where there is a Season 2,  I can hardly wait!)

I was so impressed by James Nortons' performance in `Death Comes To Pemberley' that I decided to check out other material in which he plays a main role.

This program involves Sidney Chambers an Anglican Priest and former WWII vet who is the Cannon for the Anglican church in the village of  Grantchester (near Cambridge).  He supplements his time between pastoral duties by assisting the local police detective solve crimes.  Think of him as the ecclesiastical version of Batman. The show is less about the mysteries that Sidney solves, than it is about an examination of British society in the post war period of the 1950's. Topics include racism, the class structure in England , euthanasia, marriage and homosexuality.

There is also a frank look at the life of Sidney Chambers is suffering from  PTSD as a result of what happened in the war. He could clearly be defined as a progressive minister who has a great need to be of service. However as the show goes on it appears as if he entered the ministry more as a means of assuaging his guilt and making amends than a sincere desire to serve God.  He clearly is a man of faith and wants to use that faith to help others.  But you also get the impression that he would not be a minister if it had not been for traumatic experiences he experienced in the battlefield.  Still he makes a very inspirational figure due to the fact that he is not self-righteous or preachy, and displays many human relatable human failings.

In all the program is okay, but I believe that there is much missing from the book  and which should have been kept in the series in order to make it move along smoother. One of the biggest problems I had with the show was his long time friend Amanda Kendall (played by Morven Christie). She comes across as very unsympathetic in the role.  Like a spoilt princess who decides that she wants to marry someone at her station...yet still expects Sidney to be at her beck and call and not move on.

James Norton is the best thing in the entire program. Like his character Pemberley, he cuts quite the dashing figure.  I don't think that I would ever have called a man in clerical garb `sexy' until now! I could argue that it's his weakest performance. But it has much to do with the fact that Sidney often comes across as a one dimensional goody-two shoes. But still I found him admirable.
Strongly recommended for those who like British costume mysteries and fans of James Norton.

Grantchester is yet another excellent PBS series, which is based on The Grantchester Mysteries, which are collections of short stories written by British novelist and television producer James Runcie. The story line of Grantchester centers around the extracurricular crime-solving exploits of a young Anglican vicar, who works with a veteran detective in the village of Grantchester, near Cambridge, England, in the early 1950s. Grantchester is actually a great detective procedural, which is characterized by superb writing and plot development, with murder mysteries that are intriguing, gripping, and suspenseful, replete with many interesting twists. In addition, it highlights several important cultural and societal issues that were just beginning to emerge in the forefront of the collective British consciousness during the middle of the 20th century. James Norton delivers an outstanding acting performance with his brilliant portrayal of Anglican vicar Sidney Chambers, and the acting performances of the talented members of the supporting cast are also stellar. Grantchester is a decidedly intelligent, engaging, and entertaining PBS detective series, which merits a five-star rating, along with an enthusiastic recommendation.

Why the comparisons to Chesterton?  I thought I would like this and was disappointed;  I pushed on through all 3 seasons to give it a chance to redeem itself.  Ah, redemption...funny how God is not a part of this series at all.  And that absence makes the comparison to Father Brown a ludicrous one.  At one point when Sidney is challenged about celibacy he curtly says, "I am not CATHOLIC!"  Chesterton's character, Father Brown, was steeped in his Catholic faith and reflected it as a strong, unwavering beacon of Truth.  HOW does that compare in any way to this pathetic, wavering, fellow who breaks all of the commandments?  At another point when Amanda rather sensibly asks Leonard about the Anglican Communion and their opposition to divorce when the breach with the Faith happened as a result of Henry VIII and his desire for a divorce, Leonard answers her, rather meekly, that there were more issues involved.  Window dressing.  Again, "non serviam," ...man's rebellion against God by choosing his own desires over God's commands.
The church scenes in this series show no kneeling, no praying, no liturgy...man is seemingly the "higher power" in this sanctuary because we see only Sidney back-lighted by the brilliant stained glass window as he talks to his flock not about the Mystery of Faith, not about God's Will, and God/s Grace but about ministering to each other.  When he counsels his parishioners or even when he accompanied that poor boy to the gallows, I heard no real faith.  You can't tell me this is a vicar....I didn't buy it.  I was Anglican once and my priest would not have been so humanist, so relativist.  I can hear the objections, "These are basically mystery stories;  the character is a vicar, so what?"  It does make a difference.  Only if the vicar believes his faith does it make sense to make a story line out of the indissolubility of marriage and the disordered nature of sodomy.  My Anglican priest was also an Archdeacon.  The spiritual health of the priests under his charge was of utmost importance to him;  he was their spiritual director, he did not just come to tea and drop bombshells.  This series gives a distorted view of the clergy in my opinion.  Even though I am no longer an Anglican and I believe they floated into dangerous waters in the Seventies, the Anglican Communion in the Fifties still functioned faithfully following the traditional BCP.  The problem with this series is the problem with Modernity:  remove God and man is thrust on his own devices.  The outlook becomes bleak, inevitable, and a bit boring and we watch his fall.

Since I first watched Happy Valley (outstanding show), it took me a few minutes to see James Norton as the kind, compassionate (albeit alcoholic) Vicar in Grantchester; he had been burned into my brain as the embodiment of evil from Happy Valley. Grantchester has its own layers of evil, but Norton, a WWII vet with clear PTSD and self-medicating with booze, plays the affable Sidney Chambers brilliantly. Be ready for huge "willing suspensions of disbelief" as the good Vicar becomes an honorary copper, working along side his older, but equally alcoholic and war-scarred, Inspector Geordie Keating. There are some very ridiculous scenes where, for example, the police are about to leave the station to interview a suspect, and Sidney says, "Let me go alone." And THEY LET HIM! (What the Dickens??) But, overall, you have great visuals, interesting and conflicted characters, and an underlying tale of repressed souls doing their best to make their way in post-war England. If you like the Morse, Lewis, etc., shows, you will likely appreciate Grantchester.

The stories hinge on the early 1950s friendship between a vicar and a police detective both youngish and recently returned from the atrocities of WWII. They're each heroic and equally tragic at times as they pursue their careers of helping others when they're still not certain how to help themselves in this new era of 1953. The cinematography is excellent. The plots are filled with likable characters and it doesn't hurt that the vicar, played by James Norton, appears to be a cross of early JFK and Robert Redford.. an extra incentive for the ladies in the audience, I think this series will be just what a lot of people are looking for!

British detective drama, set in the post WWII circa 1950s Cambridgeshire village of Grantchester, near Cambridge. Features a former WWII Hero who is now an Anglican Vicar, with occasional PDSD flashbacks. He develops a sideline in solving murders with a local homicide Detective Inspector, who is also a WWII veteran with a wife and several children. The series is based on The Grantchester Mysteries, collections of short stories written by James Runcie. The first series was based on the six stories from the first book, Sidney Chambers and the Shadow of Death. A second series was commissioned in late 2014 and broadcast in March and April 2016 and a third series will air in 2017. I'd like the series better if it didn't get side-tracked in the Vicar's attempts at a love life, first with a girl from his pre-war college days and then with a German woman, and then again with his girl from college, after she's married no-less.  I'm also not wild about his junior Vicar in training, who is gay, and flirting with gay relationships during an era when being gay in England would get you thrown in jail and chemically castrated. The producers need to get the Vicar trained to fight like a WWII Kings Guard, rather than a pushing pansy. Fascinating murder-mystery story lines!

It's nice to see a series that sort of presents Christians in a positive light -- at least it's free of most stereotypes. My favorite character is the gay young priest, Leonard Finch, played brilliantly by Al Weaver. He's completely endearing. From a Biblical and Christian standpoint, he is the genuine Christian. He knows he is a sinner, and he is struggling against his particular sin -- like all Christians should. He exhibits more of the Christian virtues than his worldly vicar, and I'm worried that, eventually, the series will allow the vicar to corrupt the values of his young charge. Weaver fully embodies his character and brings him to life. Every actor in the series does that. I am a little weary of the unrequited love hammer. It's like getting hit over the head by Maxwell in every episode. My second favorite character is Robson Green's hard-boiled detective, Geordie Keating. That guy's got an understated magnetism that really draws in an audience. Really impressed by this cast and charming English village. Agatha Christie and Jane Austen gave me a lifelong love of such things. However, is there no end of angst in an English village?

This is an interesting series, hard to express exactly how I feel about it.  It is similar to the Father Brown series, which I really enjoyed, but much more serious and thoughtful. The acting, the scenery, the location are all very well done. However, as a deeply religious person I'm inclined to always look for the good and positive in the world and to try to make it a better place.  I try to be a little better today than I was yesterday.  I appreciate the many challenges Sidney goes through but am disappointed when he makes poor choices.  Sure, I know the character is human and makes mistakes - so do we all.  The disappointment comes when the writer seems to deliberately portray the vicar as, well, too human.  The smoking, excessive drinking, and the occasional fornication, bring him below what would be considered a life devoted to the ministry of Jesus Christ.  I suppose others reading this would say this is exactly why the series appeals to them.  I, on the other hand, had hoped the vicar would prove to be stronger, more elevated, inspiring.  There is precious little of that in the media these days.  I should know better than to look to PBS for for inspiration, but then I am an optimist at heart.

I watched the first two seasons and just had to stop, unfortunately.  I want to rate it 5 stars and watch S3, but I'm done. While no one is perfect, a minister must have high standards and be an example to others.  Sydney showed concern and love for others but his own life is a disaster.  He constantly struggles with substance abuse, drinking too much, smoking, and making poor decisions with women.  He self-medicates instead of looking to God and the Bible for strength, wisdom, and peace.  Seriously!!?  Some minister of God.  Sydney is not genuine.  He is a phony man of God.  Geordie is more genuine, because although he has problems also, he is true to his nature and not a hypocrite.  I like Sydney and Amanda and the other characters, but I couldn't take it anymore,  along with the constant profaning of the Lord's name.
